caption: Figure 1: (a) Flowchart of the W-Bench evaluation process. (b) Watermarking performance. Each method is illustrated with a diamond and four bars. The area of the diamond represents the method's encoding capacity. The y-coordinate of the diamond's center indicates normalized image quality, calculated by averaging the normalized PSNR, SSIM, LPIPS, and FID between watermarked and input images. The x-coordinate represents robustness, measured by the True Positive Rate at a 0.1% False Positive Rate (TPR@0.1%FPR) averaged across four types of image editing methods, encompassing a total of seven distinct models and algorithms. The four bars are oriented to signify different editing tasks: image regeneration (left), global editing (top), local editing (right), and image-to-video generation (bottom). The length of each bar reflects the method's normalized TPR@0.1%FPR after each type of image editing—the longer the bar, the better the performance.
description: This chart visualizes the performance of eleven watermarking methods against four types of image editing: image regeneration, global editing, local editing, and image-to-video generation. Each watermarking method is represented by a diamond and four bars. The diamond's size indicates encoding capacity, and its vertical position shows normalized image quality (averaged PSNR, SSIM, LPIPS, and FID). The horizontal position of the diamond indicates robustness (TPR@0.1% FPR). The four bars represent the method's TPR@0.1% FPR for each editing type. Longer bars denote better performance, and the y-axis represents normalized TPR@0.1% FPR.

caption: Figure 3: Impact of various image editing techniques and distortions on the frequency spectra of images. Results are averaged over 1,000 images. Image editing methods tend to remove frequency patterns in the mid- and high-frequency bands, while low-frequency patterns remain largely unaffected. This trend is also observed with blurring distortions such as pixelation and defocus blur. In contrast, commonly used distortions like JPEG compression and saturation do not exhibit similar behavior in the frequency domain. The analysis of SVD is not included, as it removes all patterns, rendering them invisible to the human eye.
description: This chart visually represents the impact of image editing techniques and distortions on the frequency spectrum of images.  It displays the absolute difference between the Fourier transforms of edited watermarked and edited unwatermarked images for various editing methods (CtrlNet-Inpaint, Inversion, Instruct-Pix2Pix, UltraEdit) and distortions (Pixelate, Defocus Blur, JPEG Compression, Saturation). The results are averaged over 1000 images.  The chart is structured as a heatmap, showing the magnitude of frequency changes for low, mid, and high-frequency bands, revealing that image editing tends to predominantly remove patterns in mid- and high-frequency bands, while low-frequency patterns remain mostly unaffected.  This behavior is similar to blurring distortions, but not for common distortions like JPEG compression and saturation.

caption: Figure 1: (a) Flowchart of the W-Bench evaluation process. (b) Watermarking performance. Each method is illustrated with a diamond and four bars. The area of the diamond represents the method's encoding capacity. The y-coordinate of the diamond's center indicates normalized image quality, calculated by averaging the normalized PSNR, SSIM, LPIPS, and FID between watermarked and input images. The x-coordinate represents robustness, measured by the True Positive Rate at a 0.1% False Positive Rate (TPR@0.1%FPR) averaged across four types of image editing methods, encompassing a total of seven distinct models and algorithms. The four bars are oriented to signify different editing tasks: image regeneration (left), global editing (top), local editing (right), and image-to-video generation (bottom). The length of each bar reflects the method's normalized TPR@0.1%FPR after each type of image editing-the longer the bar, the better the performance.
description: This chart visualizes the performance of eleven watermarking methods against four types of image editing: image regeneration, global editing, local editing, and image-to-video generation.  Each watermarking method is represented by a diamond whose size indicates encoding capacity and whose y-coordinate shows normalized image quality. The x-coordinate of the diamond represents robustness (TPR@0.1%FPR), averaged across the four editing types. Four bars extending from each diamond further detail the method's TPR@0.1%FPR for each editing type individually.  Longer bars denote better performance, indicating higher robustness against that specific editing method.

caption: Figure 7: Performance of watermarking methods at a resolution of 512x512 pixels under (a) Gaussian blurring, (b) brightness adjustments, (c) contrast modifications, (d) Gaussian noise, and (e) JPEG compression.
description: This figure displays the performance of eleven watermarking methods across five different image distortion types: Gaussian blurring, brightness adjustments, contrast modifications, Gaussian noise, and JPEG compression.  Each subplot presents the TPR@0.1%FPR, TPR@1%FPR, bit accuracy, and AUROC for each method against varying levels of each distortion.  The x-axis of each subplot represents the level of the specific distortion applied, and the y-axis represents the performance metrics.  The figure allows for a comparison of the robustness of different watermarking methods to various types of image distortions at a consistent resolution.

caption: Figure 7: Performance of watermarking methods at a resolution of 512x512 pixels under (a) Gaussian blurring, (b) brightness adjustments, (c) contrast modifications, (d) Gaussian noise, and (e) JPEG compression.
description: This figure displays the performance of eleven watermarking methods across five different image manipulations: Gaussian blurring, brightness adjustments, contrast modifications, Gaussian noise, and JPEG compression. Each manipulation is tested across various levels of severity.  The chart shows the True Positive Rate at 1% False Positive Rate (TPR@1%FPR), bit accuracy, and AUROC for each method and manipulation type, allowing comparison of the effectiveness of each watermarking technique's robustness against different forms of image alteration and its perceptual impact.

caption: Figure 3: Impact of various image editing techniques and distortions on the frequency spectra of images. Results are averaged over 1,000 images. Image editing methods tend to remove frequency patterns in the mid- and high-frequency bands, while low-frequency patterns remain largely unaffected. This trend is also observed with blurring distortions such as pixelation and defocus blur. In contrast, commonly used distortions like JPEG compression and saturation do not exhibit similar behavior in the frequency domain. The analysis of SVD is not included, as it removes all patterns, rendering them invisible to the human eye.
description: The chart visually represents the impact of various image editing techniques and distortions on the frequency spectra of images. It uses a bar chart format to show the magnitude of frequency patterns after applying different image editing methods and distortions (e.g., Instruct-Pix2Pix, UltraEdit, pixelation, defocus blur, JPEG compression, saturation). The chart demonstrates that image editing methods primarily remove patterns in the mid and high-frequency bands, while the low-frequency patterns remain relatively unaffected.  A similar trend is also observed with blurring distortions, which is different from the other distortions like JPEG compression and saturation, implying that blurring distortions could serve as surrogate attacks for training robust watermarking models.

caption: Figure 5: The performance of watermarking methods under (a) Stochastic regeneration, (b) Global editing, and (c) Local editing. Additional results are available in Figure 16.
description: The chart displays the performance of eleven watermarking methods across various image editing techniques.  It uses TPR@0.1%FPR (True Positive Rate at 0.1% False Positive Rate) as a measure of robustness against editing.  The chart is divided into three parts: (a) Stochastic Regeneration, (b) Global Editing, and (c) Local Editing, each showing the TPR@0.1%FPR for each method across different levels of difficulty.  Additional metrics like TPR@1%FPR, bit accuracy, and AUROC are included alongside image quality measures such as PSNR, SSIM, LPIPS, and FID which are represented by the size and position of diamonds for each method. The length of the bars for each method represent the normalized TPR@0.1%FPR after each type of image editing.

caption: Figure 7: Performance of watermarking methods at a resolution of 512x512 pixels under (a) Gaussian blurring, (b) brightness adjustments, (c) contrast modifications, (d) Gaussian noise, and (e) JPEG compression.
description: This figure displays the performance of eleven watermarking methods across five different image distortion types: Gaussian blurring, brightness adjustments, contrast modifications, Gaussian noise, and JPEG compression.  Each distortion type is shown in a separate subplot (a-e). Within each subplot, multiple performance metrics (TPR@0.1%FPR, TPR@1%FPR, bit accuracy, and AUROC) are plotted against different levels of the respective distortion. For example, subplot (a) shows the effect of increasing Gaussian blurring kernel size on watermark robustness. This allows for a visual comparison of how different watermarking techniques withstand various types and levels of image distortions.

caption: Figure 7: Performance of watermarking methods at a resolution of 512x512 pixels under (a) Gaussian blurring, (b) brightness adjustments, (c) contrast modifications, (d) Gaussian noise, and (e) JPEG compression.
description: This figure displays the performance of eleven different watermarking methods across five different image manipulation techniques. Each subfigure shows the impact of a specific type of image manipulation (Gaussian blurring, brightness adjustments, contrast modifications, Gaussian noise, and JPEG compression) on the true positive rate (TPR) at 0.1% false positive rate (FPR) and TPR at 1% FPR, bit accuracy, and area under the ROC curve (AUROC). The x-axis of each subfigure represents the level or strength of the manipulation applied. For example, Gaussian blurring shows varying kernel sizes. For each watermarking method, a line graph shows the performance across the range of manipulations. This allows for a comparison of the methods' robustness to various image editing attacks.

caption: Figure 5: The performance of watermarking methods under (a) Stochastic regeneration, (b) Global editing, and (c) Local editing. Additional results are available in Figure 16.
description: This figure displays the performance of eleven watermarking methods across three different image editing techniques: Stochastic regeneration, global editing, and local editing.  Each method is represented by a different color, and its performance is shown as four bars corresponding to the four types of image editing for each of the methods. The length of each bar is proportional to the True Positive Rate (TPR) at a 0.1% False Positive Rate (TPR@0.1%FPR), which is a measure of the method's robustness against image editing.  The y-axis shows the TPR@0.1%FPR, ranging from 0 to 1. The x-axis shows the different image editing tasks, with the four bars representing image regeneration, global editing, local editing, and image-to-video generation respectively.  The area of a diamond for each method represents the method's encoding capacity, and its vertical position reflects the normalized image quality of the watermarked images.

caption: Figure 5: The performance of watermarking methods under (a) Stochastic regeneration, (b) Global editing, and (c) Local editing. Additional results are available in Figure 16.
description: The chart displays the performance of eleven watermarking methods across various image editing techniques.  It shows the True Positive Rate at 0.1% False Positive Rate (TPR@0.1%FPR) for each method under four types of image editing: stochastic image regeneration (with varying noise timesteps), global image editing (with varying text guidance scales using MagicBrush), local image editing (with varying mask ratios using UltraEdit), and image-to-video generation (using Stable Video Diffusion).  Each method's performance is represented by a set of four bars, one for each editing type, and the length of the bar reflects the TPR@0.1%FPR.  A diamond indicates the method's encoding capacity and image quality (normalized PSNR, SSIM, LPIPS, and FID).

caption: Figure 7: Performance of watermarking methods at a resolution of 512x512 pixels under (a) Gaussian blurring, (b) brightness adjustments, (c) contrast modifications, (d) Gaussian noise, and (e) JPEG compression.
description: This figure displays the performance of eleven watermarking methods across five different image distortions at a resolution of 512x512 pixels.  Each subplot represents a specific distortion type (Gaussian blurring, brightness adjustments, contrast modifications, Gaussian noise, and JPEG compression).  For each distortion, the chart shows how the True Positive Rate at 0.1% False Positive Rate (TPR@0.1%FPR), TPR@1%FPR, bit accuracy, and AUROC change across varying levels of intensity for each distortion.  The performance of the different watermarking methods is shown, allowing comparison of robustness under various distortion types.

caption: Figure 5: The performance of watermarking methods under (a) Stochastic regeneration, (b) Global editing, and (c) Local editing. Additional results are available in Figure 16.
description: This chart displays the performance of eleven different watermarking methods across three types of image editing: stochastic regeneration, global editing, and local editing.  For each method, four bars represent its performance (TPR@0.1%FPR) after each editing type, with longer bars indicating better robustness.  A diamond overlaid on each set of bars shows the method's encoding capacity (area) and normalized image quality (y-coordinate). The x-coordinate of the diamond shows the average robustness across all editing types.  The chart visually compares the trade-offs between robustness to image editing and image quality for different watermarking techniques.

caption: Figure 5: The performance of watermarking methods under (a) Stochastic regeneration, (b) Global editing, and (c) Local editing. Additional results are available in Figure 16.
description: This figure displays the performance of eleven watermarking methods across three different image editing techniques: Stochastic regeneration, Global editing, and Local editing.  For each method, there are four bars representing its performance for each editing technique.  The length of each bar shows the True Positive Rate at 0.1% False Positive Rate (TPR@0.1%FPR), a measure of the robustness of the watermarking method against the particular editing technique.  Additionally, each method is represented by a diamond, the area of which denotes its encoding capacity. The y-coordinate of the diamond shows normalized image quality, and the x-coordinate indicates the average TPR@0.1%FPR across all editing techniques.

caption: Figure 7: Performance of watermarking methods at a resolution of 512x512 pixels under (a) Gaussian blurring, (b) brightness adjustments, (c) contrast modifications, (d) Gaussian noise, and (e) JPEG compression.
description: This figure displays the performance of eleven watermarking methods across five different image manipulation techniques: Gaussian blurring, brightness adjustments, contrast modifications, Gaussian noise addition, and JPEG compression.  Each graph presents the True Positive Rate at 0.1% False Positive Rate (TPR@0.1%FPR), TPR@1%FPR, bit accuracy, and AUROC against varying levels of intensity for each manipulation.  The x-axis represents the level of the manipulation, while the y-axis shows the performance metric.  The figure allows for a comparison of the robustness of different watermarking methods to various image distortions.

caption: Figure 7: Performance of watermarking methods at a resolution of 512x512 pixels under (a) Gaussian blurring, (b) brightness adjustments, (c) contrast modifications, (d) Gaussian noise, and (e) JPEG compression.
description: This figure displays the performance of eleven different watermarking methods across five different image distortions at a resolution of 512x512 pixels. Each subplot represents a different distortion type: (a) Gaussian blurring, (b) brightness adjustments, (c) contrast modifications, (d) Gaussian noise, and (e) JPEG compression. For each distortion, the performance is measured in terms of TPR@0.1%FPR, TPR@1%FPR, Bit Accuracy, and AUROC across a range of distortion levels (e.g., varying kernel sizes for Gaussian blur). The chart allows a visual comparison of the robustness of different watermarking methods against various image distortions and helps in identifying the methods that maintain high detection accuracy even under significant distortions.

caption: Figure 7: Performance of watermarking methods at a resolution of 512x512 pixels under (a) Gaussian blurring, (b) brightness adjustments, (c) contrast modifications, (d) Gaussian noise, and (e) JPEG compression.
description: This figure displays the performance of eleven different watermarking methods across five different image manipulation techniques. Each subfigure represents a different manipulation: Gaussian blurring, brightness adjustments, contrast modifications, Gaussian noise, and JPEG compression. For each manipulation, the chart shows the performance of each watermarking method using four metrics: TPR@0.1%FPR, TPR@1%FPR, bit accuracy, and AUROC. The x-axis of each chart represents the level of manipulation applied, while the y-axis represents the value of each performance metric. The chart allows for a comparison of the robustness of different watermarking methods against different types of image manipulation.

caption: Figure 7: Performance of watermarking methods at a resolution of 512x512 pixels under (a) Gaussian blurring, (b) brightness adjustments, (c) contrast modifications, (d) Gaussian noise, and (e) JPEG compression.
description: This figure displays the performance of eleven watermarking methods across five different types of image distortions at a resolution of 512x512 pixels. Each subfigure represents a specific distortion type: (a) Gaussian blurring, (b) brightness adjustments, (c) contrast modifications, (d) Gaussian noise, and (e) JPEG compression. For each distortion, the x-axis represents the severity level of the distortion, and the y-axis shows different performance metrics: TPR@0.1%FPR, TPR@1%FPR, bit accuracy, and AUROC.  The different watermarking methods are represented by different colored lines, allowing for a comparison of their robustness to each distortion.

caption: Figure 7: Performance of watermarking methods at a resolution of 512x512 pixels under (a) Gaussian blurring, (b) brightness adjustments, (c) contrast modifications, (d) Gaussian noise, and (e) JPEG compression.
description: This figure displays the performance of eleven different watermarking methods across five types of image distortions at a resolution of 512x512 pixels. Each of the five subfigures represents a different type of distortion: (a) Gaussian blurring, (b) brightness adjustments, (c) contrast modifications, (d) Gaussian noise, and (e) JPEG compression. For each distortion type, the x-axis represents the level or strength of the distortion, while the y-axis shows the TPR@0.1%FPR (True Positive Rate at 0.1% False Positive Rate), TPR@1%FPR, bit accuracy, and AUROC (Area Under the Receiver Operating Characteristic curve). The performance of each watermarking method is represented by a different colored line.  The chart allows for a comparison of the robustness of different watermarking methods against various types of image distortions and the impact of the distortion level on detection accuracy.

caption: Figure 5: The performance of watermarking methods under (a) Stochastic regeneration, (b) Global editing, and (c) Local editing. Additional results are available in Figure 16.
description: This chart visualizes the performance of eleven different watermarking methods across three types of image editing: stochastic image regeneration, global image editing, and local image editing.  For each editing type, the chart presents the True Positive Rate at 0.1% False Positive Rate (TPR@0.1%FPR) for each watermarking method across different difficulty levels.  The difficulty levels are represented by varying parameters: noise timestep for stochastic regeneration, text guidance scale for global editing, and mask ratio for local editing. The chart allows for a comparison of the robustness of different watermarking methods against various image editing techniques and their performance across different difficulty levels within each technique.  It shows that our method (VINE-B and VINE-R) outperforms other methods in most categories.

caption: Figure 5: The performance of watermarking methods under (a) Stochastic regeneration, (b) Global editing, and (c) Local editing. Additional results are available in Figure 16.
description: This chart displays the performance of eleven watermarking methods across three different image editing techniques: stochastic image regeneration, global image editing, and local image editing.  For each editing technique, the chart shows the True Positive Rate at a 0.1% False Positive Rate (TPR@0.1%FPR) for each method across multiple difficulty levels.  The x-axis represents the difficulty level (noise timestep for regeneration, text guidance scale for global editing, and mask ratio for local editing), while the y-axis represents the TPR@0.1%FPR.  Diamonds show encoding capacity and normalized image quality; each of the four bars represent the robustness of each method to one of the four image editing tasks.

caption: Figure 7: Performance of watermarking methods at a resolution of 512x512 pixels under (a) Gaussian blurring, (b) brightness adjustments, (c) contrast modifications, (d) Gaussian noise, and (e) JPEG compression.
description: This figure showcases the performance of eleven watermarking methods across five different image manipulation techniques: Gaussian blurring, brightness adjustments, contrast modifications, Gaussian noise, and JPEG compression. Each sub-figure presents the TPR@0.1%FPR, TPR@1%FPR, bit accuracy, and AUROC for each watermarking method, plotted against the increasing severity of each manipulation. For instance, sub-figure (a) shows performance changes as Gaussian blurring kernel size increases, while (e) demonstrates the effect of increasing JPEG compression factor.  The chart allows comparison of how robust each watermarking method is against various image editing attacks, illustrating the trade-off between robustness and watermarking quality.

caption: Figure 5: The performance of watermarking methods under (a) Stochastic regeneration, (b) Global editing, and (c) Local editing. Additional results are available in Figure 16.
description: This chart presents a comparison of the performance of eleven watermarking methods across different image editing techniques.  For each method, four bars represent its True Positive Rate (TPR) at a 0.1% False Positive Rate (FPR) after applying four types of image editing (image regeneration, global editing, local editing, and image-to-video generation). A diamond represents each method, where the area of the diamond denotes encoding capacity, the y-coordinate shows the normalized image quality, and the x-coordinate indicates the robustness against image editing.  The chart visually compares the effectiveness of different watermarking methods in maintaining watermark integrity despite various image manipulations.

caption: Figure 1: (a) Flowchart of the W-Bench evaluation process. (b) Watermarking performance. Each method is illustrated with a diamond and four bars. The area of the diamond represents the method's encoding capacity. The y-coordinate of the diamond's center indicates normalized image quality, calculated by averaging the normalized PSNR, SSIM, LPIPS, and FID between watermarked and input images. The x-coordinate represents robustness, measured by the True Positive Rate at a 0.1% False Positive Rate (TPR@0.1%FPR) averaged across four types of image editing methods, encompassing a total of seven distinct models and algorithms. The four bars are oriented to signify different editing tasks: image regeneration (left), global editing (top), local editing (right), and image-to-video generation (bottom). The length of each bar reflects the method's normalized TPR@0.1%FPR after each type of image editing—the longer the bar, the better the performance.
description: This chart visualizes the performance of eleven watermarking methods across four image editing techniques: image regeneration, global editing, local editing, and image-to-video generation.  Each watermarking method is represented by a diamond, where the size corresponds to its encoding capacity and the x and y coordinates denote robustness (TPR@0.1%FPR) and image quality respectively. Four bars extend from each diamond, representing the method's robustness against each editing technique.  The length of each bar is proportional to the method's normalized TPR@0.1%FPR for that editing task.  The chart effectively compares the methods' performance across various image editing types, enabling a holistic assessment of their robustness and image quality.

caption: Figure 1: (a) Flowchart of the W-Bench evaluation process. (b) Watermarking performance. Each method is illustrated with a diamond and four bars. The area of the diamond represents the method's encoding capacity. The y-coordinate of the diamond's center indicates normalized image quality, calculated by averaging the normalized PSNR, SSIM, LPIPS, and FID between watermarked and input images. The x-coordinate represents robustness, measured by the True Positive Rate at a 0.1% False Positive Rate (TPR@0.1%FPR) averaged across four types of image editing methods, encompassing a total of seven distinct models and algorithms. The four bars are oriented to signify different editing tasks: image regeneration (left), global editing (top), local editing (right), and image-to-video generation (bottom). The length of each bar reflects the method's normalized TPR@0.1%FPR after each type of image editing-the longer the bar, the better the performance.
description: This chart visualizes the performance of eleven watermarking methods against various image editing techniques.  The chart is composed of two parts. Part (a) presents a flowchart illustrating the evaluation process of W-Bench, a comprehensive benchmark for evaluating the robustness of watermarking methods against various image editing techniques including regeneration, global and local editing, and image-to-video generation. Part (b) displays the performance of eleven watermarking methods using a combination of diamonds and bars. Each method is represented by a diamond, where the area reflects encoding capacity and the x and y coordinates represent robustness (TPR@0.1% FPR) and image quality respectively. Four bars extending from each diamond further break down the robustness against each of four image editing types: image regeneration, global editing, local editing, and image-to-video generation, with bar length proportional to performance.
